mn106:1.1.comm: This sutta describes practices that lead to attaining the formless meditations: three ways to attain the “imperturbable”, three ways to continue to the dimension of nothingness, and finally a way to attain neither perception nor non-perception. One theme of the text is that deep states of absorption are supported by reflective wisdom. The sutta concludes by teaching what is beyond all these, namely not grasping.

mn106:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kurūsu viharati kammāsadhammaṃ nāma kurūnaṃ nigamo.
mn106:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kurus, near the Kuru town named Kammāsadamma.

mn106:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn106:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, sensual pleasures are impermanent, hollow, false, and deceptive.

mn106:2.2.eng: This is made by illusion, mendicants, lamented by fools.
mn106:2.2.comm: This phrase is sometimes translated as if it was joined to the previous. However, the repeated use of bhikkhave, the shift from plural to singular, and the independent occurrence of the former portion (AN 10.46:6.5) all suggest it is a distinct sentence. | As for bālalāpana, at SN 22.95:13.2 we find bālalāpinī in a similar context, which there follows right after the death of the physical body. This suggests that lāpinī there has the sense “lament” which is attested in Sanskrit. Bālalāpana is found at Thig 5.2:2.2 of a beautiful body; see too Ja 421:5.3. In later Sanskrit, bālalapitaṁ is used by Jayarāśi Bhaṭṭa in his Tattvopaplavasiṁha in the sense “prattle of fools”.

mn106:2.3.pli: Ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā, ye ca samparāyikā kāmā;
mn106:2.3.eng: Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,

mn106:2.4.pli: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā kāmasaññā—
mn106:2.4.eng: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come;

mn106:2.5.pli: ubhayametaṃ māradheyyaṃ, mārassesa visayo, mārassesa nivāpo, mārassesa gocaro.
mn106:2.5.eng: both of these are Māra’s dominion, Māra’s domain, Māra’s lair, and Māra’s range.

mn106:2.6.pli: Etthete pāpakā akusalā mānasā abhijjhāpi byāpādāpi sārambhāpi saṃvattanti.
mn106:2.6.eng: They conduce to bad, unskillful notions such as desire, ill will, and aggression.

mn106:2.7.eng: And they create an obstacle for a noble disciple training here.

mn106:3.1.eng: A noble disciple reflects on this:

mn106:3.2.pli: ‘ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā, ye ca samparāyikā kāmā;
mn106:3.2.eng: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,

mn106:3.3.pli: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā kāmasaññā—
mn106:3.3.eng: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come;

mn106:3.4.pli: ubhayametaṃ māradheyyaṃ, mārassesa visayo, mārassesa nivāpo, mārassesa gocaro.
mn106:3.4.eng: both of these are Māra’s dominion, Māra’s domain, Māra’s lair, and Māra’s range.

mn106:3.5.pli: Etthete pāpakā akusalā mānasā abhijjhāpi byāpādāpi sārambhāpi saṃvattanti,
mn106:3.5.eng: They conduce to bad, unskillful notions such as desire, ill will, and aggression.

mn106:3.6.eng: And they create an obstacle for a noble disciple training here.

mn106:3.7.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ vipulena mahaggatena cetasā vihareyyaṃ abhibhuyya lokaṃ adhiṭṭhāya manasā.
mn106:3.7.eng: Why don’t I meditate with an abundant, expansive heart, having mastered the world and stabilized the mind?

mn106:3.8.pli: Vipulena hi me mahaggatena cetasā viharato abhibhuyya lokaṃ adhiṭṭhāya manasā ye pāpakā akusalā mānasā abhijjhāpi byāpādāpi sārambhāpi te na bhavissanti.
mn106:3.8.eng: Then I will have no more bad, unskillful notions such as desire, ill will, and aggression.

mn106:3.9.pli: Tesaṃ pahānā aparittañca me cittaṃ bhavissati appamāṇaṃ subhāvitan’ti.
mn106:3.9.eng: And by giving them up my mind, no longer limited, will become limitless and well developed.’

mn106:3.10.pli: Tassa evaṃpaṭipannassa tabbahulavihārino āyatane cittaṃ pasīdati.
mn106:3.10.eng: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.

mn106:3.11.pli: Sampasāde sati etarahi vā āneñjaṃ samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati.
mn106:3.11.eng: Being confident, they either attain the imperturbable now, or are freed by wisdom.
mn106:3.11.comm: The Pali has paññāya vā adhimuccati (“they resolve with wisdom”). This appears to be an old confusion between adhimuccati (“resolves”) and vimuccati (“is freed”). Elsewhere in Pali we find one who is “freed by wisdom” (eg. SN 22.45:1.6) but we don’t find adhimuccati used in this way. The commentary accepts the reading adhimuccati, but explains it as referring to either the realization of arahantship or the development of the path to arahantship, which agrees with the idea of “freedom”. Finally, the Chinese parallel (MA 75 at T i 542b23) has 解, while the Tibetan parallel in Śamathadeva’s commentary on the Abhidharmakośabhāṣya (D (4094) mngon pa, ju 228a2) has rnam par grol ba, both of which appear to translate vimuccati. If this reading is accepted, it also adds greater coherence to the sutta as a whole, for after discussing the various ways to the imperturbable, the final section is devoted to the “noble liberation”, where vimokkha is a synonym of vimutti (MN 106:13.3).

mn106:3.12.pli: Kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā, ṭhānametaṃ vijjati yaṃ taṃsaṃvattanikaṃ viññāṇaṃ assa āneñjūpagaṃ.
mn106:3.12.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the imperturbable.
mn106:3.12.comm: Saṁvattanika means “conducive, leading to”. The state of consciousness developed in meditation leads to a rebirth in a plane where the normal level of consciousness is that of the corresponding meditation attainment. Thus if they have developed the fourth absorption, they will be reborn in a corresponding Brahmā realm.

mn106:3.13.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamā āneñjasappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyati.
mn106:3.13.eng: This is said to be the first way of practice suitable for attaining the imperturbable.

mn106:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:

mn106:4.2.pli: ‘ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā, ye ca samparāyikā kāmā;
mn106:4.2.eng: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,

mn106:4.3.pli: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā kāmasaññā;
mn106:4.3.eng: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come;

mn106:4.4.pli: yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ sabbaṃ rūpaṃ cattāri ca mahābhūtāni, catunnañca mahābhūtānaṃ upādāyarūpan’ti.
mn106:4.4.eng: whatever form there is, all form is the four principal states, or form derived from the four principal states.’

mn106:4.5.pli: Tassa evaṃpaṭipannassa tabbahulavihārino āyatane cittaṃ pasīdati.
mn106:4.5.eng: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.

mn106:4.6.pli: Sampasāde sati etarahi vā āneñjaṃ samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati.
mn106:4.6.eng: Being confident, they either attain the imperturbable now, or are freed by wisdom.

mn106:4.7.pli: Kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā, ṭhānametaṃ vijjati yaṃ taṃsaṃvattanikaṃ viññāṇaṃ assa āneñjūpagaṃ.
mn106:4.7.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the imperturbable.

mn106:4.8.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyā āneñjasappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyati.
mn106:4.8.eng: This is said to be the second way of practice suitable for attaining the imperturbable.

mn106:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:

mn106:5.2.pli: ‘ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā, ye ca samparāyikā kāmā;
mn106:5.2.eng: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,

mn106:5.3.pli: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā kāmasaññā;
mn106:5.3.eng: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come,

mn106:5.4.pli: ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpā, ye ca samparāyikā rūpā;
mn106:5.4.eng: visions in this life and in lives to come,
mn106:5.4.comm: Here rūpa is neither “matter” nor “sights” but “visions” seen in meditation.

mn106:5.5.pli: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā rūpasaññā—
mn106:5.5.eng: perceptions of visions in this life and in lives to come;

mn106:5.7.pli: Yadaniccaṃ taṃ nālaṃ abhinandituṃ, nālaṃ abhivadituṃ, nālaṃ ajjhositun’ti.
mn106:5.7.eng: And what’s impermanent is not worth approving, welcoming, or clinging to.’

mn106:5.8.pli: Tassa evaṃpaṭipannassa tabbahulavihārino āyatane cittaṃ pasīdati.
mn106:5.8.eng: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.

mn106:5.9.pli: Sampasāde sati etarahi vā āneñjaṃ samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati.
mn106:5.9.eng: Being confident, they either attain the imperturbable now, or are freed by wisdom.

mn106:5.10.pli: Kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā, ṭhānametaṃ vijjati yaṃ taṃsaṃvattanikaṃ viññāṇaṃ assa āneñjūpagaṃ.
mn106:5.10.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the imperturbable.

mn106:5.11.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyā āneñjasappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyati.
mn106:5.11.eng: This is said to be the third way of practice suitable for attaining the imperturbable.

mn106:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:

mn106:6.2.pli: ‘ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā, ye ca samparāyikā kāmā;
mn106:6.2.eng: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,

mn106:6.3.pli: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā kāmasaññā;
mn106:6.3.eng: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come,

mn106:6.4.pli: ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpā, ye ca samparāyikā rūpā;
mn106:6.4.eng: visions in this life and in lives to come,

mn106:6.5.pli: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā rūpasaññā;
mn106:6.5.eng: perceptions of visions in this life and in lives to come,

mn106:6.8.pli: Yatthetā aparisesā nirujjhanti etaṃ santaṃ etaṃ paṇītaṃ—
mn106:6.8.eng: Where they cease without anything left over, that is peaceful, that is sublime,

mn106:6.9.comm: As in MN 105:12.3, the “imperturbable” here appears to refer to the fourth absorption and first two formless attainments.

mn106:6.10.pli: Tassa evaṃpaṭipannassa tabbahulavihārino āyatane cittaṃ pasīdati.
mn106:6.10.eng: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.

mn106:6.11.pli: Sampasāde sati etarahi vā ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati.
mn106:6.11.eng: Being confident, they either attain the dimension of nothingness now, or are freed by wisdom.

mn106:6.12.pli: Kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā, ṭhānametaṃ vijjati yaṃ taṃsaṃvattanikaṃ viññāṇaṃ assa ākiñcaññāyatanūpagaṃ.
mn106:6.12.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the dimension of nothingness.

mn106:6.13.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamā ākiñcaññāyatanasappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyati.
mn106:6.13.eng: This is said to be the first way of practice suitable for attaining the dimension of nothingness.

mn106:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati:
mn106:7.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:

mn106:7.2.eng: ‘This is empty of a self or what belongs to a self.’

mn106:7.3.pli: Tassa evaṃpaṭipannassa tabbahulavihārino āyatane cittaṃ pasīdati.
mn106:7.3.eng: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.

mn106:7.4.pli: Sampasāde sati etarahi vā ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati.
mn106:7.4.eng: Being confident, they either attain the dimension of nothingness now, or are freed by wisdom.

mn106:7.5.pli: Kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā, ṭhānametaṃ vijjati yaṃ taṃsaṃvattanikaṃ viññāṇaṃ assa ākiñcaññāyatanūpagaṃ.
mn106:7.5.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the dimension of nothingness.

mn106:7.6.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyā ākiñcaññāyatanasappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyati.
mn106:7.6.eng: This is said to be the second way of practice suitable for attaining the dimension of nothingness.

mn106:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:

mn106:8.2.pli: ‘nāhaṃ kvacani kassaci kiñcanatasmiṃ, na ca mama kvacani kismiñci kiñcanaṃ natthī’ti.
mn106:8.2.eng: ‘I don’t belong to anyone anywhere! And nothing belongs to me anywhere!’
mn106:8.2.comm: This reflection occurs three times in the Pali. At AN 4.185:7.2 it leads to the dimension of nothingness for a brahmin. It leads to the same attainment in a Buddhist context here (compare AN 5.144:7.2). At AN 3.70:3.11 it is said to be a Jain practice.

mn106:8.3.pli: Tassa evaṃpaṭipannassa tabbahulavihārino āyatane cittaṃ pasīdati.
mn106:8.3.eng: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.

mn106:8.4.pli: Sampasāde sati etarahi vā ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati.
mn106:8.4.eng: Being confident, they either attain the dimension of nothingness now, or are freed by wisdom.

mn106:8.5.pli: Kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā, ṭhānametaṃ vijjati yaṃ taṃsaṃvattanikaṃ viññāṇaṃ assa ākiñcaññāyatanūpagaṃ.
mn106:8.5.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the dimension of nothingness.

mn106:8.6.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyā ākiñcaññāyatanasappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyati.
mn106:8.6.eng: This is said to be the third way of practice suitable for attaining the dimension of nothingness.

mn106:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:

mn106:9.2.pli: ‘ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā, ye ca samparāyikā kāmā;
mn106:9.2.eng: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,

mn106:9.3.pli: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā kāmasaññā;
mn106:9.3.eng: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come,

mn106:9.4.pli: ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpā, ye ca samparāyikā rūpā;
mn106:9.4.eng: visions in this life and in lives to come,

mn106:9.5.pli: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā rūpasaññā;
mn106:9.5.eng: perceptions of visions in this life and in lives to come,

mn106:9.6.pli: yā ca āneñjasaññā, yā ca ākiñcaññāyatanasaññā—
mn106:9.6.eng: perceptions of the imperturbable, and perceptions of the dimension of nothingness;

mn106:9.8.pli: Yatthetā aparisesā nirujjhanti etaṃ santaṃ etaṃ paṇītaṃ—
mn106:9.8.eng: Where they cease without anything left over, that is peaceful, that is sublime,

mn106:9.9.eng: namely the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’

mn106:9.10.pli: Tassa evaṃpaṭipannassa tabbahulavihārino āyatane cittaṃ pasīdati.
mn106:9.10.eng: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.

mn106:9.11.pli: Sampasāde sati etarahi vā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati.
mn106:9.11.eng: Being confident, they either attain the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception now, or are freed by wisdom.

mn106:9.12.pli: Kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā, ṭhānametaṃ vijjati yaṃ taṃsaṃvattanikaṃ viññāṇaṃ assa nevasaññānāsaññāyatanūpagaṃ.
mn106:9.12.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

mn106:9.13.eng: This is said to be the way of practice suitable for attaining the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.”

mn106:10.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn106:10.1.eng: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:

mn106:10.2.eng: “Sir, take a mendicant who practices like this:

mn106:10.3.pli: ‘no cassa, no ca me siyā; na bhavissati, na me bhavissati; yadatthi yaṃ, bhūtaṃ—taṃ pajahāmī’ti.
mn106:10.3.eng: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’
mn106:10.3.comm: See Bodhi’s extensive discussion in his translation of SN 22.55:1.3 (Connected Discourses, vol. iii, note 75). This formula appears several times throughout the suttas, in two forms: the personal form used by non-Buddhists (“I might not be …”, eg. SN 22.81:12.8, AN 10.29:19.1), and the impersonal form as adapted by the Buddha here (“It might not be …”). The formula seems to have a shared among different sectarian groups, like the similar reflection above (MN 106:8.2. But whereas that reflection is associated with Brahmans and Jains—both classified as “eternalists”—this view is said to be that of the “annihilationists” (SN 22.81:11.10).

mn106:10.4.eng: In this way they gain equanimity.

mn106:10.5.pli: Parinibbāyeyya nu kho so, bhante, bhikkhu na vā parinibbāyeyyā”ti?
mn106:10.5.eng: Would that mendicant become extinguished or not?”

mn106:10.6.pli: “Apetthekacco, ānanda, bhikkhu parinibbāyeyya, apetthekacco bhikkhu na parinibbāyeyyā”ti.
mn106:10.6.eng: “One such mendicant might become extinguished, Ānanda, while another might not.”

mn106:10.7.pli: “Ko nu kho, bhante, hetu ko paccayo yenapetthekacco bhikkhu parinibbāyeyya, apetthekacco bhikkhu na parinibbāyeyyā”ti?
mn106:10.7.eng: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason for this?”

mn106:10.8.eng: “Ānanda, take a mendicant who practices like this:

mn106:10.9.pli: ‘no cassa, no ca me siyā; na bhavissati, na me bhavissati; yadatthi, yaṃ bhūtaṃ—taṃ pajahāmī’ti.
mn106:10.9.eng: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’

mn106:10.10.eng: In this way they gain equanimity.

mn106:10.11.pli: So taṃ upekkhaṃ abhinandati, abhivadati, ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
mn106:10.11.eng: They approve, welcome, and keep clinging to that equanimity.

mn106:10.12.pli: Tassa taṃ upekkhaṃ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato tannissitaṃ hoti viññāṇaṃ tadupādānaṃ.
mn106:10.12.eng: Their consciousness has that as support and fuel for grasping.

mn106:10.13.eng: A mendicant with fuel for grasping does not become extinguished.”

mn106:11.1.pli: “Kahaṃ pana so, bhante, bhikkhu upādiyamāno upādiyatī”ti?
mn106:11.1.eng: “But sir, what is that mendicant grasping?”

mn106:11.2.eng: “The dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.”

mn106:11.3.pli: “Upādānaseṭṭhaṃ kira so, bhante, bhikkhu upādiyamāno upādiyatī”ti?
mn106:11.3.eng: “Sir, it seems that mendicant is grasping the best thing to grasp!”

mn106:11.5.eng: For the best thing to grasp is

mn106:11.6.eng: the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

mn106:12.1.eng: Take a mendicant who practices like this:

mn106:12.2.pli: ‘no cassa, no ca me siyā; na bhavissati, na me bhavissati; yadatthi, yaṃ bhūtaṃ—taṃ pajahāmī’ti.
mn106:12.2.eng: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’

mn106:12.3.eng: In this way they gain equanimity.

mn106:12.4.pli: So taṃ upekkhaṃ nābhinandati, nābhivadati, na ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
mn106:12.4.eng: They don’t approve, welcome, or keep clinging to that equanimity.

mn106:12.5.pli: Tassa taṃ upekkhaṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato na tannissitaṃ hoti viññāṇaṃ na tadupādānaṃ.
mn106:12.5.eng: So their consciousness doesn’t have that as support and fuel for grasping.

mn106:12.6.eng: A mendicant free of grasping becomes extinguished.”

mn106:13.2.pli: Nissāya nissāya kira no, bhante, bhagavatā oghassa nittharaṇā akkhātā.
mn106:13.2.eng: It seems the Buddha has explained to us how to cross over the flood by relying on one support or another.
mn106:13.2.comm: This passage shows how the method of attaining such states is secondary, as one might practice it well and yet still have clinging. Any of these “supports”, i.e. the various methods taught above, suffices to develop the mind, but what matters is letting go. | “One support or another” (nissāya nissāya) appears at DN 16:4.27.2, where it means “right beside”. For the sense “support” in this context, compare Iti 107:2.3: “supporting each other … in order to cross over the flood” (aññamaññaṁ nissāya … oghassa nittharaṇatthāya).

mn106:13.3.eng: But sir, what is noble liberation?”

mn106:13.4.eng: “Ānanda, it’s when a noble disciple reflects like this:

mn106:13.5.pli: ‘ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā, ye ca samparāyikā kāmā;
mn106:13.5.eng: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,

mn106:13.6.pli: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā kāmasaññā;
mn106:13.6.eng: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come,

mn106:13.7.pli: ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpā, ye ca samparāyikā rūpā;
mn106:13.7.eng: visions in this life and in lives to come,

mn106:13.8.pli: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā rūpasaññā;
mn106:13.8.eng: perceptions of visions in this life and in lives to come,

mn106:13.9.pli: yā ca āneñjasaññā, yā ca ākiñcaññāyatanasaññā, yā ca nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññā—
mn106:13.9.eng: perceptions of the imperturbable, perceptions of the dimension of nothingness, perceptions of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception;

mn106:13.10.eng: that is substantial reality as far as substantial reality extends.

mn106:13.11.pli: Etaṃ amataṃ yadidaṃ anupādā cittassa vimokkho.
mn106:13.11.eng: But this is freedom from death, namely the liberation of the mind through not grasping.

mn106:14.1.pli: Iti, kho, ānanda, desitā mayā āneñjasappāyā paṭipadā, desitā ākiñcaññāyatanasappāyā paṭipadā, desitā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasappāyā paṭipadā, desitā nissāya nissāya oghassa nittharaṇā, desito ariyo vimokkho.
mn106:14.1.eng: So, Ānanda, I have taught the ways of practice suitable for attaining the imperturbable, the dimension of nothingness, and the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. I have taught how to cross the flood by relying on one support or another, and I have taught noble liberation.

mn106:15.1.pli: Yaṃ kho, ānanda, satthārā karaṇīyaṃ sāvakānaṃ hitesinā anukampakena anukampaṃ upādāya, kataṃ vo taṃ mayā.
mn106:15.1.eng: Out of sympathy, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples.

mn106:15.2.pli: Etāni, ānanda, rukkhamūlāni, etāni suññāgārāni. Jhāyathānanda, mā pamādattha, mā pacchā vippaṭisārino ahuvattha. Ayaṃ vo amhākaṃ anusāsanī’”ti.
mn106:15.2.eng: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption, Ānanda! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction to you.”

mn106:15.3.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn106:15.4.pli: Attamano āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mn106:15.4.eng: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
